facts.text: Village Khand Gawadi had a panchayat before October 1958 with Gangaram as Sarpanch and Ram Narain (appellant) as Up-Sarpanch.
In April and May 1958, appellant officiated for Sarpanch Gangaram who was busy with his daughter's marriage.
Rajasthan Government gazette notification No. 1128/F.1(48)L59/A/55 dated 16-10-58 extended limits of Municipal Council, Kota to Khand Gawadi.
Municipal Council took over charge from Gram Panchayat of Khand Gawadi on January 7, 1959.

Between November 1959 to January 1960, long after panchayat ceased to exist, appellant allegedly conspired with Madan Mohan, Badriprasad, Bakshi Gajpatsingh, Bhanwarlal (approver) and others to forge pattas and sale proceedings for lands to Moolsingh, Mukatbeharilal and Surajsingh, forging signatures, thumb impressions of panchas, cash book entries, and affixing seal.
Appellant charged under ss. 467, 468, 420, 120B IPC along with three others in Sessions Court, Kota.

Sessions Judge convicted appellant under ss. 467 and 120B IPC, sentenced to RI 3 years + Rs.200 fine (6 months def.) under 120B and RI 2 years + Rs.200 fine (6 months def.) under 467, concurrent; acquitted others.

Rajasthan High Court affirmed conviction on ss. 467 and 120B, reduced sentence to RI 15 months + Rs.200 fine (3 months def.) on each count, concurrent; judgment dated April 17, 1970 in S.B. Cr. Appeal No. 283 of 1967.

Bhanwarlal (PW1) granted pardon, became approver, deposed about being introduced to appellant in June 1958, buying plot, paying Rs.40, receiving patta 30x45, later shown 30x35, helping appellant forge ~200 pattas including those for Surajsingh (Exs P5,P6), Moolsingh (P9), Mukatbeharilal (P12).

On April 7, 1970, appellant applied in High Court under s.540 CrPC to recall Gangaram (PW3) for cross-exam on prior complaints and enmity, examine Mukat Beharilal (withheld, filed writ in SC) and Dy SP (IO) as court witnesses.

High Court did not deal with or refer to April 7, 1970 application in judgment; slip showed it in Judge's chamber; Dy Registrar order April 29, 1970 to keep on file per Judge; s.561A application April 30/May1, 1970 not listed/heard; Judge's order May 18, 1970 rejected without hearing counsel.
Gangaram (PW3, ex-Sarpanch) filed complaint Ex P-19 on March 18, 1961 to Collector Kota alleging misappropriation; prior complaints not substantiated; enmity with appellant.

Pattas: Surajsingh Exs P5,P6 (May 5,1958, 30x35 each? 100 sq yds, Rs37.50+2 bhaint, deposited); order sheet P4; Moolsingh P9 (100 sq yds, Rs30+2 bhaint); order P8; Mukatbeharilal P12 (227 sq yds+7 sq ft, Rs100 incl plan fee, receipt M.B.Sharma); order P11.
Defence witnesses: Madan Lal (DW1) present at 1958 sale to Mukatbeharilal, identified sigs on P11; Ghasi (DW2) admitted sigs on P11; Babulal (PW5) illiterate, couldn't identify sigs.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court failed to consider the appellant's application under s.540 CrPC to recall PW3 and summon witnesses, resulting in miscarriage of justice.
Whether appellant's conviction under ss.467 and 120B IPC is sustainable solely on uncorroborated testimony of approver PW1 Bhanwarlal.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court did not consider or refer to application dated April 7, 1970 to recall Gangaram PW3 (due to subsequent acquittal in related case revealing enmity), examine Mukat Beharilal and IO; s.561A application disposed without hearing; miscarriage of justice.
Conviction based solely on unreliable, uncorroborated testimony of approver PW1 whose evidence is discrepant, unconvincing; no corroboration connecting appellant to forgery or conspiracy.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.133 Evidence Act read with illus (b) s.114

respondent_arguments.text: Defended conviction under ss.467 and 120B IPC based on approver's evidence and documents.

court_reasoning.text: Application under s.561A disposed without hearing counsel was wrong; divergence in records leaves unhappy impression, but unnecessary to decide as appeal allowed on merits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant has just grievance but probe unnecessary.

court_reasoning.text: Approver's testimony admissible under s.133 Evidence Act but prudence requires corroboration in material particulars connecting accused to crime per illus (b) s.114; evaluate approver first, then corroboration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Approver suspect, may falsely implicate innocents.

court_reasoning.text: Approver PW1's evidence uninspiring: unclear motive to help, prepared 200 pattas but only 4 led, disclosed post-arrest.

No evidence of cheating (consideration < market or misappropriated); focus on forgery of valuable security (patta) under s.467 IPC (false document intent to defraud per s.463; valuable security per s.30).
Surajsingh pattas P5,P6 signed by appellant, no forged sigs; order P4: approver bald claim, Babulal PW5 can't identify, Ghasi not questioned; no reliable corroboration.
Moolsingh P9 similar, signed by appellant; Mukatbeharilal P12: Ghasi DW2 admits sigs on P11; defence witnesses confirm 1958 sales; PW2 Surajsingh doesn't support cheating; PW3 Gangaram enmity.
No independent evidence of conspiracy under s.120B; approver not believed on forgery, can't sustain conspiracy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Inferences from unaccepted criminal acts insufficient.

holdings.text: Conviction under ss.467 and 120B IPC unsustainable without corroboration of approver's testimony.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences of forgery of valuable security and criminal conspiracy charged and analysed.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Approver competent but requires corroboration as rule of prudence.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Application to recall/summon witnesses; disposal of s.561A application.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; conviction and sentences under ss.467 and 120B IPC set aside; appellant acquitted.

key_quotes.text: an accomplice is unworthy of credit unless he is corroborated in material particulars.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rule of prudence from illus (b) s.114 Evidence Act.

key_quotes.text: the courts as a matter of prudence and caution anxiously look for some corroboration to satisfy their conscience that the approver's testimony... is also worthy of belief.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains necessity and nature of corroboration for approver evidence.

key_quotes.text: In face of this material, we find that the appellants conviction under s.467 I.P.C. is wholly unsustainable on the existing evidence.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Conclusion on lack of corroboration for forgery charges.
